utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: And that is I’ve just recently noticed in myself that I've been learning. And that's a big deal. Uh, I hear people say all the time, “Oh, I've learned so much, I learned this and I learned that and that was such a learning experience.” And I, all these years that I've been grown up, I haven't felt any learning, and I feel, “Well, what did you learn and how did you know that you learned it?” And it was a mystery to me. And just the last few weeks, or actually I've been realizing in the last year mainly is that I’ve learned some things and I know I've learned them and I, I know that, okay, that I'm at this point and with a certain situation or idea and that six months ago or three months ago it was different. And so I'm feeling my learning and that's really exciting.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And it’s the awareness of it that's new. That you're beginning to realize, “Hey, I am different in this respect, I've learned something.”

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: I've changed. And I can see the difference and feel the difference. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: What are some of those differences?

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Well, um, I, I've made a decision to be more strict with my children and to, uh, to listen to them but decide that I'm their mother and I know many things they don't, and that I will make many more decisions than I've made in the past. And uh-

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm, m-hm. Sounds as though you feel a bit stronger that way.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Yes. And and I've been trying it. Trying being the more strict person and it's working beautifully. Uh, they at first they, you know, have their little resistance or whatever it is but then we go on with the program, which is my program more, and I feel a lot better about that as being uh uh helping children to adjust to the world.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I mean, sounds, sounds like you feel more like a grown-up mother.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. Capable. Of making appropriate decisions. For them. And another area is sex. And, uh, and I, I've done a lot of things in the past year, in the past mainly year that I haven't done before. That is, I've had intercourse with a few different men and put myself in situations where before I was absolutely unwilling to do because of my fears and, and I've learned some things about myself. Like I know a lot more right now today about what kind of sexual relationship, what kind of intimate relationships that I want to have with men and that feels good. Beca ... and, um, and it only came through, uh, risking I mean there was no, it only became through trying things out, there was no amount There was no amount of, of therapy or reading or thinking or talking that helped me to learn those things, but it was feeling strong enough within myself that I can take chances.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So risking has been the road to learning in the sexual area.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Uh-huh. And it is with my children and it is with relating to people in many ways, not just sexually. Other ways too. to talk about things like this on film. But what's more important is that she has come to the point in her own life where, where she realizes that her own experience is the best guide for her, not books, not therapy, not anything outside of herself. It is her own experience from which she can learn, and here she is learning in a very sensitive and, uh, personal area and is willing to share that with us.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Reaching out to people and approaching strangers and, uh ...

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Taking all kinds of risks that you hadn't before.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Some. More, which, I mean I, I don't know about all kinds. Quite a few, and it's been exciting and hard.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And I guess that leads to a, uh, to a deeper kind of learning, or at any rate, a learning that you feel more sure of. I guess, I get a sense of assurance in what you're talking about. An assurance in you. is that she thinks carefully about what she says, she thinks carefully about what I say, and when what I say is not correct, doesn't match her experience, she's quite willing to correct me. She is very precise in both describing her own feelings and also in making sure that my response to them is also accurate.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Well, yes. Yes and no. And I ... I ... feel more im... like I, I was saying before, I feel more immature and more and I'm more aware of my immaturity. They're both, uh, a part of each other. And uh, does that make, does that, I guess I'm thinking that it just sounds crazy.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: No, I don't

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: To say that I feel more mature because I know I'm how, I know more about how immature I am.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uh-huh. No, that makes a lot of sense to me. thought that it made sense to me, but that doesn't necessarily mean it would make sense to other people. I mean, it made in my own system of what was said. It felt good that he could understand me and he knew I that, that it made sense to him too.] Can anyone understand how she can be more mature by being aware of her immaturity? Well, to me, that's quite understandable, but it's clear that she wants to make certain that my understanding extends to that degree.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: It does.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uh-huh. Because you’re, you're uh more aware of all aspects of yourself and it sounds a more acceptant of them too. “Yes, I'm mature in certain ways and here's some ways I know I'm immature.”

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: And I didn't know that before, or I, I knew I felt uncomfortable that I didn't understand it. But that's related to something I've been thinking about, I think, about being here with you and, uh, and telling myself two things. One is, “Oh, you're just a, I'm just a dependent personality,” you know, Carl Rogers or blah-blah-blah-blah, don't, I don't run my own life. I go for help a lot. And then I tell myself I’ve always been so strong and so together and having everything so worked out in my head that I don't allow myself to, to be helpless in a situation where it might be good for me. Like right now here with you, I would like to be more helpless, which to me means open, I think. To what to us and, uh, and I see myself being, uh, together and not being helpless. another session of being all in control of things and and rattling on and on. I probably made a conscious decision that that I have to do something to, to break that and, uh, which was talk about it, talk about my fear. My fear was or concern that I wouldn't learn anything.]

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Sounds as though you, you voice that as a conflict, but it sounds as though really you're more on the, on the side of the second aspect that, uh, uh, to be open and, and in that sense helpless and vulnerable, I guess might be a possible term too, um, is something you, you really believe that's what you are, rather than that you're a totally dependent person and really helpless and have to, have to run for help. I sort of get the feeling you like this aspect of you that is able to be with me in a way that is, uh, more open, more vulnerable perhaps.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Well, I like it and I also scold myself for being dependent, so there's

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: There are the two sides, uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: there's something missing in the middle to connect, and I it seems like you might have been talking about that and I still didn't hear it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm. So really to get it more accurately, you scold yourself for for being dependent, for, for wanting to be here, for example, with me, and yet at the same time you, you feel. uh, well, that's good, I, I really like that, but where's the, where's the integration of those two, uh, points of view. when he, you know, tells me back what he thinks I meant, it, um, solidified what I expressed in the previous comment about that there was something missing. It made more sense to me.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: That's right. May I hold your hands again?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Sure. M-hm.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: To feel that old feeling.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Okay. whole time, and I imagine that it occurred me that it might be good to do that again. I feel good. At that time, I, I wanted to get away from being in my head so completely the whole time, experiencing.] of a friend of mine who said that he did eye therapy and, uh, in a sense that's what this was. Our eyes were very much in contact, and, uh, I think as much was going on at a non-verbal way as in a verbal way. It was a close relationship, and we both experienced it that way.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: I would like to be less, uh, less strong right now. I would like to give myself the gift of not having to be sensible and reasonable and Also the protection, protect, protect myself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm, m-hm, m-hm. utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: And I think it helps to touch you, to, to, to let go of the shoulds, of my

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm, m-hm. And you feel some contact and maybe you can say, “Well, maybe I don't have to be so strong, so Maybe I can just let go more.”

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Yes. I want to get away from all, um, my rationalizing right now this minute, and I don't know how to do that except to shut up. And, so it's not like I have so much a desire to sit and not talk and look in your eyes as I have a desire to not be the way I am all the time. And I don't know yet what else to do. and Sylvia found a, a great deal of security and, uh, seemed to profit a great deal from holding my hands during the interview, and here she, uh, returns to the pattern of a year ago. It's another indication of the fact that these interviews with her perhaps rest more solidly on just the fact of the relationship than they do even on the content of what, uh, she's saying and talking about.]

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Have to be kind of silent, to let go of that rational and rationalizing part of you.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. It feels easier to focus on, uh, in this position that I'm in now with you I feel more focused, yeah.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Are there any things that sort of come bubbling up?

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Yeah, I know it's something I want to talk about.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Okay. M-hm. But it's not easy, huh.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: No, it's not easy and I'm enjoying the richness of feeling your hands this way and letting go of some more of, of the camera business and the ... And, uh, and the fear about bringing up something that and knowing that in about fifteen minutes it'll all seem, um, could say the words that I needed to say. It was almost like waiting and just like, uh, you know, what else is new while I'm waiting? For something that took a natural process that it had to take.] removed by this interchange. Sylvia's saying, “I'm doing more work when I'm silent than I am when I'm talking.”] necessarily helpful as opposed to not helpful, but what it does do that is valuable is that it gives me something to bounce against. It's a stimulation to better focus myself.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: There's something I've been wanting to talk over with you.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Okay.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Good. I'm real attracted to black people. And, uh, that's about the craziest part of me, um, I'm ashamed Um, I'm embarrassed, not right now this minute, but when I'm out walking around. And living my life.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You feel what an awful thing it is that I'm attracted to black people. felt that she probably was going to make use of that closer relationship to get to something that she hadn't been able to express before, and now she's taking really a great risk in talking about something very private, very personal.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Not, and not all the black people I see but a lot. And, uh, like the black people that I talked it over with, it seems, it doesn't seem like any problem at all, they understand perfectly. And, but my family, I think it's a real painful situation for them when I have as many black friends as I do. And-

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That sounds like not only your family looks down on it or something but that you scold yourself for it too.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Uh-huh, right. I, I think there's something wrong with me.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah, that's it.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Um. But it doesn't-

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “What kind of a crazy person am I that I feel attracted to so many blacks?”

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Sick, sick I think of it as

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Sick, that's

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: and ne... neurotic, um. Strange.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You really feel that there's something sick in you that causes you to have so many black friends.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Well, I keep looking for a reasonable explanation and there is none.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So there isn't any reason except that you feel that way.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. And I ...

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And that isn't good enough.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Well, I, I, I've been struggling so long to accept that in myself and I'm still fighting. It's like I'm fighting to accept that in myself and, and letting go rather than thinking it's a terrible thing and and that I can't let other people know. And, uh,

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You feel “I should not feel that way. I shouldn't be that way. Sick.” order to assist her in, uh, becoming more accepting of them, but as I, uh, listen to it I think I might have responded more powerfully by responding to her struggle to accept herself as a person who is attracted to blacks.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Like when I, wh ... , I imagine when I meet a black person that I am attracted to, that that person will know and I always wonder if they can tell.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Mm, see if it shows. M-hm, m-hm.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: And that they'll think I'm strange. M-hm. And it has something to do with all the black/white sex stuff that goes on, like, um, black women and white men which is very foreign to me, I have very little thinking or, um, concern about that. But the black men/white women thing, um. and I'm attracted to a lot of black men. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It has something to do with the sexual attraction.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: I know, yeah, it does, I know it does. But it's not just that, it's also children and and women and lifestyle and as I see it through my tunnel vision, which I do.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So I guess you're saying, um, yeah, there's a sexual element in it but I'm also attracted to their way of living.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. That I see. And I, but I think what I see isn't what is.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's partly your fantasy or something.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Maybe putting that, that, this on this film will help me that stand on the ground and be who I am. And not be so ashamed, so embarrassed and so, um, uncomfortable.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: In a way you're saying it out loud and really in a wa ..., in a sense, publicly, may help you to feel “I don't need to be so ashamed of that.” knowingly make use of the filming to try to gain more acceptance of self and clearly that's what Sylvia is doing in this interchange. By putting herself clearly on record, she feels perhaps then she will feel less ashamed, less sick, more, uh, truly acceptant of the person that she is and the experiences that she has.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: And I tell myself I should be joyful, I mean, why, why negative? And I, I guess, you know, the culture or I don't know, I

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But you feel disapproved of probably, certainly by your family and maybe by the culture in this respect.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: My friends don't understand. My white friends.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm, m-hm. Makes you feel different. Set apart or something like that.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Well, sometimes I feel different but I know a lot of other people, I believe a lot of other people feel the same way. and I know a lot of other white women are attracted to black men. So I believe that's common.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So that somehow you know you're not alone in this. attitudes she has toward her own attraction to blacks leads her to realize this really is not so bad after all; there are positive sides of it. Other people, other women feel the same way.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: But it seems like the strength of my feelings and, uh, the on-goingness and my de ..., my desire to identify with the black culture and, um, is. is what seems out of proportion to me. That I feel out of proportion about it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm. So Okay, other women feel the same way but not to the degree that you do, you think. That's kind of out of Out of scale.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Or in general to the degree too, not just man/woman, but people. Maybe I, it'll come a time accepting that part of myself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Maybe someday you won't be ashamed of yourself for that.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. Maybe someday I can be proud of myself. And for what I believe and feel. And I'm gradually learning to do that.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uh-huh, m-hm. So, perhaps what you are and what you feel will be something you can take real satisfaction in instead of feeling how shameful.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. And to me it's it's a sign of my growth is being able to do what I'm doing with you now, you'll make a film. It's a real brazen thing to do. M-hm.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Feel this is a risk. And that's a sign of learning and of growth.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. Well, also it somehow it's a little different from a risk in the sense of some of my friends say, “A film? Wh... What do you want to do that for?” I mean, there's suspiciousness about it and …

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm, m-hm. So that's seen as another strange part of you.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Well, not so much, I mean, that's not a

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Not so.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: It doesn't bother me. Sometimes I, well, right now sometimes, I have the sense of talking away what we were talking about and I'm wondering, if I went away, if I withdraw from the subject, uh, what's your perspective? It seems like we were talking about my attraction to black people and now we're not. And I'm, I don't know, like did we finish talking about it or did I withdraw? experiencing. I don't believe that in content we had left the subject of her attraction to blacks. But she realizes in herself that somehow she has withdrawn from that. She's, as she says, talked away from it. Obviously, that's because it has been a, a frightening subject to her. Perhaps also because she feels she's gone as far as she can go with it at the present time.]

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Um

utterances.speaker: therapist

utterances.speaker: client

utterances.speaker: therapist

utterances.speaker: client

Sylvia, like many other clients, hardly knows what she has said because it has come so close to her inner feelings, because it’s such a delicate experience. Incidentally, this is one point where a wrong response on the part of the counselor can be very frightening and very threatening because her inner self is really very exposed at this point. This inability to remember is the, uh, defense of the self against being changed too rapidly. It probably would be very good for her to hear this later and to begin to accept more fully what she's just been expressing.]

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “What did I say? What did I feel?” You'd like to have a rerun of it and it

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. Like I just went jabber-jabber-jabber-jabber. And all that. And so-

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Sounds like you scold yourself for that, as though, “Oh, I just talk talk-talk.” It didn't sound like just talk-talk-talk to me.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: It didn't?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: No. empathic and caring ones. Here's the first time that I express some other feeling of my own. I simply couldn't permit her to scold herself for what she's been doing, and so I said, “It doesn't sound like, uh, just talk-talk-talk to me,” which was a very real feeling on my part at that moment.] something that he wanted to know. utterances.speaker: client

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: That's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “And part of that attraction is sexual but I'm also attracted to their children, to the way they live, to a lot of things about them.” of myself and I do in this moment.]

utterances.speaker: client

utterances.speaker: client

I can simply accept it. Perhaps I can simply accept it." I admire Sylvia's courage in being willing to voice the very, uh, intimate feelings she has on film. I believe that both the expression of those feelings will be constructive for her and that the willingness to share them with a wider audience will also have a positive effect in her life.]

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “If I could accept it, I wouldn't have to understand in the sense of knowing the reasons.”

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Or explain to anybody. M-hm.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Sounds like that's what you're doing in imagination a lot, trying to explain it to somebody.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: M-hm. It seems like I'll probably never understand it. So I can make life a lot easier for myself by not trying.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm. It may be one of those things that if you can accept it, you wouldn't need to have all the explanations.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Wonder what what keeps me, um, feeling like I need to justify myself. Like that's a more basic

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm. It's a broader statement of it.

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: than about a particular view, accepting myself about this and about that.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: M-hm. You would in general feel “I have to justify myself with proper reasons.”

utterances.speaker: client

utterances.speaker: therapist

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: So there's nobody that just floats along on their intuition. That’s not it either. So what I need is more balance really. Not that I’m wrong to justify it, but that I can be more, justify it less and feel more, one of the things about it that feels real close to me is the emotional safety I felt with him. That there was somehow a, a boundary or a fence or a something that, uh, separated the space that I was in with Carl from the rest of the world and inside that space I was very safe and I would not be hurt. I didn't have to have any fear that I would be hurt no matter what I said or did, and the focus of my thinking was how very safe that felt. Another thing I felt from him that I think has affected me some over this time is that I felt, uh, like support from him to be myself, to listen to myself and to respond to myself and to care about, to put myself first. I think about how my life might have been changed by my experiences with Carl. I think Carl's caring for me in the way that he did, his, uh, modeling, helping me to learn to care for myself, where like maybe my most important resource would be myself. So it seems to me that in his style of relating there's a lot of support to do that, a lot of encouragement and influence to listen to myself.]
